required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Exercise and Baseline Respiratory Functional Tests Among Obese Teenagers
clinical_study.official_title: Exercise and Baseline Respiratory Functional Tests Among Obese Teenagers

brief_summary.textblock:
In obese adolescents, the severity of obesity should not influence the outcome of resting PFT. The amplitudes of the rest PFT should make it possible to predict the performance achieved while exercising on a cycloergometer.
We wish to highlight the presence of a significant correlation, probably low, between some respiratory parameters at rest, and cardio-vascular parameters at the exercise.

primary_outcome.measure: Correlation between resting respiratory parameters and cardio-respiratory parameters at exercise
primary_outcome.description: Correlation between resting respiratory parameters: total lung capacity (TLC), forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), forced vital capacity (FVC) and cardio-respiratory parameters at exercise: maximal oxygen uptake (VO2 max), power achieved during incremental testing (Pmax), blood gas, at the time of the pulmonary function test.

intervention.intervention_name: Correlation between resting respiratory parameters and cardio-respiratory parameters at exercise
intervention.description: Correlation between resting respiratory parameters and cardio-respiratory parameters at exercise

study_pop.textblock: Obese teenagers with previous PFT available in the medical record

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children aged >12 y.o and <18 y.o
- BMI > 30
- with a previous pulmonary function test (PFT) available in the medical record
